lines.text: I've been a kid, and I've been an adult. And believe me, adultery isn't what it's cracked up to be.
I need help.
We know that. But Mom won't let us have you committed.
...It's not fair. I yelled dibbies on the bed.
Tracy has a point, Mom. Seems to me that we should all get a chance to vote. After all, this is a democracy.
Well, I certainly don't want to be undemocratic. So, I vote for the bed; and since you two are too young to vote, I win.
Danny, come here.

[Walks over to Reuben]
Yeah?
Go away.
You can't blame me. I'm just a kid.
No, you're not. You're a midget in a kid suit.
Tracy, it's your turn to say grace.
Dear Lord, thank you for our food, and please get Keith a date.
Danny, if you'd like to go to the beach with me, I'll let you swim in the riptide.
Riptides are dangerous.
Aw, who told you that?
I guess every family has to have a black sheep. I always thought ours was Keith.
Keith, don't you ever knock before coming into a person's room?
You're not a person, you're my sister.
...Keith, that's the meanest, rottenest and dirtiest trick anyone can play on his sister. No wonder you're my idol.
...If six ducks are on a pond and three more ducks land on the pond, what would you have?
Several hundred duck hunters.
Every daughter wants her mother to marry a doctor.
...You can read about it when I write my memoirs, "The Thrilling Adventures of Reuben Kincaid"!
It'll be a thin book.
It's not normal for kids to be quiet. I might end up maladjusted.
Whatever gave you the idea you could operate your own Lonely Hearts Club?
I didn't think I was doing anything wrong. What you said is, "Reuben needs a wife."
I need a *what*?
I told them to get you a goldfish, but they wouldn't listen.
what you think now will last forever, probably won't; what you're *sacrificing* *will*... You have no idea what I'm trying to say, do you?
You know, I wish you'd read the story of Evel Knievel.
Why's that?
Well, then maybe you might go take a flying leap.
There's no sense in waiting up. Laurie's in good hands.
That's what I'm afraid of.
...I wouldn't worry about him. He's an archaeologist. He can always dig up a girl.
Well, kids, how do you like performing in an amusement park?
Great! But it would be *perfect* if cotton candy was deductible.
You know we think a lot alike.
I know and sometimes it scares me.
...Honey, I'm curious about something. It's purely hypothetical, of course. But suppose a boy were very interested in you when you weren't interested in him. How do you...
Get rid of Bernie?
Well, it has been a while since I've done that kind of thing.
Well, you could start off by mentioning that you two have absolutely nothing in common.
That's right. We don't.
Then you can tell him that you're a very independent woman. You know, a loner.
A loner? With five kids?
Those are my two best ones, Mom.
...I have got the greatest news!
You're taking your own apartment?
...Good day.
It was until now.
...The army hasn't admitted making a mistake since 1952.
What happened in 1952?
They drafted me.
You're always the center of attention.
...I appreciate your volunteering to take the kids to the beach, but it just doesn't sound like you.
since I'm the eldest male, I have a lot of influence on them. Besides, I'm old enough to accept my responsibilities and give them the kind of leadership they need.
Keith, have you been talking to a Marine recruiter?
...I think the whole thing taught me a lesson.
What's that?
I don't know yet. But there must be a lesson in there somewhere for all this suffering.
...I just can't believe it! Keith Partridge flunking sex education! Well, he and I finally have something in common.
Reuben, they didn't teach sex education when you went to high school.
Yeah, I know. But I flunked it anyway.
...You have my word as a gentleman.
Thanks, but I'd rather have someone watching you.
You have *five* children?
That's right.

[to her son Bernie, who is dating Shirley]
And you knew this?
[he nods. Mrs. Applebaum pauses]
Well, I guess it's good for taxes.

[Keith and Danny are waiting for Laurie to come home from a date with a minister. She enters the front door]
Well?
Well, what?
Tell us what a minister does on a date!
I bet he took you to see the Ten Commandments.
No. Too racy.
What makes you think we went to a movie?
C'mon, fill us in on the details.
You really want to know where we went?
Yeah.
Well, we couldn't decide on what movie to see, so... We went straight to Muldoon's Point.
[she goes upstairs]
I wonder how *he* explains lipstick on his collar?

[Reuben's car is stuck in deep sand on an American Indian Reservation. A group of men in full Indian dress and war paint appear on horseback]
I don't suppose you gentlemen are from the Auto Club...?

[to Danny]
No wonder you have red hair. Your brain is rusted!
What do eleven-year-olds do on a date?
I don't know. They can't neck, Danny doesn't have one.
Wish I'd said that.
Mmmm. Glad I did.
Danny, when will Keith be able to pay back the money he owes us?
If I have it my way, he'll be able to pay in about a year.
A year!
If Keith has it his way, we'll have to wait for the reading of his will.
You know, it takes a warped mind to think of women as a hobby.
I'd rather collect stamps.
Reuben, why is it you always manage to drop in when I bake an apple pie?
He gives me a dime to tell him.
I hate to not-eat-and-run, but I gotta go.
Look, I just want to play music the best way I know how. Now is that wrong?
This date is an opportunity.
I thought you considered every date an opportunity.
Danny, if you're ever thinking of running away from home, do it.
When you're well-known, it's an opportunity to set a good example.
In fact, it's an obligation.
Free speech is great, until it's someone else speaking.
...Are you saying my friends are ding-a-lings?
Not all of them. Only the ones I've met.
C'mon, let's play a game, Mr. Kincaid.
Yeah, let's play a game.
Okay, okay. Let's play a game called "Lost."
How do you play?
Well, I'll hide my eyes and you three kids run away from home - far and fast - and keep running until you're lost.
Then what?
In three weeks, I'll come look for you. If I find you, I lose.
What if you *don't* find us?
Well, then I win.
All's fair in love and Parchessi
If man was supposed to sing in high places, he would have been born a soprano.
I think it's wonderful the way this whole family pitches in to help.
You know, Mom... If you weren't always busy cleaning the house, you wouldn't be so tired.
...Shirley, trust me.
That's asking too much.
...You know, we think a lot alike.
I know. And sometimes it scares me.
...You know, Shirley, I was thinking...
In Mr. Kincaid's case, that can be dangerous.
...That's our Keith. Talented, handsome, and wishy-washy.
...So, as an attorney, what do you think of Perry Mason?

...Let me explain something to you. I'm your mother, and in that way I'll always belong to all of you. But I'm also a woman. And even with five children whom I love very much, and who I know love me, there are times when I still feel lonely.
...Keith, if men like you had their own country, Hugh Hefner would be king.
...A Partridge never forgets. I have a photographic mind.
Sure you do; unfortunately, you always forget to load the film in it.
...Don't you think one genius in the family is enough?
Who might that be?
Modesty prevents me from stating the obvious.
Danny...!
Well, at least I know my limitations. All I want to be is Howard Hughes.
Then why don't you disappear?
I refuse to get into a battle of wits with an unarmed man.
...Here's my compass. It doesn't work, though. It always points in the same direction.
...I'm not going to fight you, Goose. I'll fight you for something I believe in, but I'm not going to fight you just because you're ego's hurt. It's just not a good enough reason.
...You know, we'll laugh about this in five or ten years - whenever we get out of prison.
...I'm beginning to realize that responsibilities are something you have to assume gradually.
Well, you are a little young to be raising four kids.
I'm old enough to handle them, all right. It just doesn't leave enough time to do my homework.
...Keith, we can't gamble with our family. They're worth a lot more than $156. Even Tracy.
...Tell me, did your mother ever tell you not to play in traffic?
Of course.
Too bad.
A dry client equals a broke manager.

[to Shirley]
... Look, you don't want to be a mother to a bunch of illiterate bums, do you?
He's right, Mom. Do you want Chris to pump gas all his life, and Tracy to wait on tables in some sleazy strip joint, while I work as a garbage collector... just because you were chicken?
He may not be able to talk for days.
...Mom, if I get into any trouble I can always run for help. I don't need Keith to do it for me.
...Danny, there's more to life than taking bows.
Not when you're an egomaniac with grease paint in your blood.
...I've spied on Keith on lots of dates. Don't bother.
...Now that you've got a million dollars, what's the first thing you're going to do?
Gloat.
Besides that.
Invest it.
I think the first thing I'm going to do is charter a boat and sail to the Caribbean.
Great. I'll rent it to you.
Why don't you buy a boat, Keith?
Because I bought it first.
What are you going to do, Chris?
Buy a catcher's mitt...
No wonder you're so short. You think small.
...But then I'm going to buy the Los Angeles Dodgers.
I'm not selling.
...Chris, Tracy, you'll both understand when you're my age... although *I'm* my age and *I* don't understand.
Tracy, don't put that drumstick up your nose!
Why not?
You don't know where it's been!
It all started when I lost my pickle!
Hey, kid. You want to be among friends?
Yeah!
Go stand in front of a bug light.
I don't know. You people have a live record date in two days and all I get is, "Rueben, he just walked in the door".
Why couldn't I take a nice SAFE job? Like milking cobras!
Look at these prices!
You are looking at the King.
I didn't know dummies had a King.

[referring to Danny]
Where's the big typhoon?
You mean *tycoon*.
A typhoon is a big wind.
I know what I said!

[on the warpath, to Danny]
There you are, you red-headed hamburger!
They'd leave *me* for Mick Jagger?
Who could live without a car or a girlfriend?
I could, I do it all the time.
Now that I understand, I wish I didn't understand.

[the Partridge Family bus detours through the woods en route to their next gig. Danny takes Chris and Tracy for a walk. Tracy and Chris return sans Danny; both are covered with mud, and beaming excitedly]
What happened to you guys? You're a mess!
Danny found this great place to play!
And he didn't come back with you two? Where *is* Danny?

[off in the distance]
HEEELP!
[That "great place to play" turns out to be a pool of quicksand]
Mom I've got something I need to tell you.
Don't tell me your leaving the group already.
Of Course not.
I told you not to tell me.
In this day and age, anything can happen. Love does not ask to see your I.D.
All you guys think we're interested in is being cheerleaders or homecoming queens. And then, if we're real lucky, we can all grow up to be Playboy bunnies.
All's fair in love and Parcheesi.
...Well, to me love is total. It's a direct communication between two people. The key word is honesty.
Right. When you love someone you know you can trust them. That's another big part of it. Trust.
Yes, but you have to earn that. You can't just take it.
Sure you can. Haven't you ever heard of stolen kisses?
